page.title: 18ASHTON - ARCHAEOLOGY
page.content: A Roman town once existed beside the River Nene at Ashton. In recent years there has been a lot of excavation on the site by pupils from Prince William School, Oundle and others organised by the Nene Valley Archaeological Group. There were initially no visible signs of the settlement, but archaeologists then revealed the foundations of buildings, pottery and jewellery. Evidence now suggests that the settlement once covered some thirty acres of what then became agricultural land. The remains also extend below the site of the old Oundle railway station where a series of Roman burials have been found. The construction of the Oundle bypass was the spur to the most recent 'dig' for which permision was given by the land- owner, the Hon.Mrs.Lane.
